name: Kwak No-pi
summary: Kwak No-pi was a Joseon Dynasty architect and engineer who designed the Gyeonghoeru Pavilion at Gyeongbokgung Palace, one of Korea's most iconic architectural structures. His engineering feat created a large banquet hall standing on 48 stone columns over an artificial lake, demonstrating advanced architectural and hydraulic engineering in 15th century Korea.

name: Nam Sa-go
summary: Nam Sa-go was a Joseon Dynasty scholar known for his geomantic (pungsu) predictions and his systematic approach to studying geographical features for site selection. While geomancy is not modern science, his careful observation and classification of landforms represented an early systematic approach to Korean geographical analysis.

name: Kim Jeong-hui
summary: Kim Jeong-hui was a Joseon Dynasty scholar who pioneered epigraphy (the study of inscriptions) in Korea. He used scientific methods to authenticate and date historical inscriptions, applying rigorous textual analysis. His systematic approach to studying historical artifacts anticipated modern archaeological methodology in Korea.
timeline: Studied epigraphy and calligraphy in China

name: Yu Gil-jun
summary: Yu Gil-jun was a late Joseon Dynasty intellectual who was the first Korean to study in the West (attending Boston's Governor Dummer Academy). He wrote Seoyu Gyeonmun (Observations from the Western Journey), introducing Western science, technology, and political systems to Korean readers. His work was pivotal for Korean modernization.
timeline: Visited Japan as part of study mission

name: Kim Ok-gyun
summary: Kim Ok-gyun was a Korean political reformer who advocated for modernization based on Western science and technology. He led the Gapsin Coup of 1884 attempting to modernize Korea along Japanese Meiji-style lines, including scientific education reform. Though the coup failed and he was later assassinated, his ideas influenced Korean modernization.

name: Ji Seok-yeong
summary: Ji Seok-yeong was a Korean physician who introduced smallpox vaccination to Korea in 1879, saving countless lives. He learned the vaccination technique from Japanese physicians and implemented vaccination programs across Korea. He is considered the pioneer of modern preventive medicine in Korea.

name: Seo Jae-pil
summary: Seo Jae-pil (Philip Jaisohn) was the first Korean to become a naturalized American citizen and the first Korean to earn an American medical degree. He founded Korea's first modern newspaper (The Independent) and introduced modern scientific concepts to Korean readers. He promoted scientific thinking as essential for Korean independence and modernization.
timeline: Born in Boseong, Jeolla Province, Korea
Participated in Gapsin Coup, fled to United States
Earned MD from Columbian University (George Washington)
Founded The Independent newspaper in Korea

name: Yun Chi-ho
summary: Yun Chi-ho was a Korean diplomat and educator who studied at Vanderbilt University and Emory University. He promoted Western science education in Korea and helped establish modern educational institutions. His extensive diaries provide detailed observations of scientific and technological developments he witnessed during the Enlightenment period of Korea.
timeline: Studied at Vanderbilt and Emory Universities

name: Kim Yeon-su
summary: Kim Yeon-su was a Korean industrialist who founded what became the Samyang Group, Korea's first modern industrial conglomerate. He established Korea's first sugar refinery and textile factory using modern technology. His application of industrial technology to Korean manufacturing helped lay the groundwork for Korea's later industrialization.
timeline: Born in Koch'ang, Jeolla Province, Korea

name: Cho Man-sik
summary: Cho Man-sik was a Korean independence activist and educator known as the 'Korean Gandhi.' He promoted Korean self-sufficiency through indigenous industry and technology development. His Korean Products Promotion Movement encouraged the development of Korean manufacturing capabilities and technological self-reliance.
timeline: Led interim government in northern Korea

name: Yi Gwang-su
summary: Yi Gwang-su was a Korean writer and intellectual who, though primarily a novelist, was one of the first Korean intellectuals to systematically introduce Western scientific and philosophical ideas through his writings. His emphasis on rational thinking and modern education influenced Korea's intellectual modernization.

name: Arai Hakuseki
summary: Arai Hakuseki was a Japanese Confucian scholar and statesman who advanced rational and empirical approaches to knowledge during the Edo period. He interviewed a captured Italian priest, Giovanni Battista Sidotti, producing Seiyo Kibun (Record of Western Things), one of the first Japanese works systematically documenting Western geography, religion, and technology.
timeline: Became advisor to Shogun Tokugawa Ienobu
Published Seiyo Kibun (Record of Western Things)

name: Ino Tadataka
summary: Ino Tadataka was a Japanese cartographer who produced the first accurate map of Japan through 17 years of land surveying on foot. Beginning at age 55, he walked the entire coastline of Japan, measuring distances with remarkable precision. His maps, completed posthumously by his students, were so accurate they were used for over a century.
timeline: Complete map of Japan published posthumously

name: Mutsu Munemitsu
summary: Mutsu Munemitsu was a Japanese diplomat and statesman who as Foreign Minister successfully renegotiated the unequal treaties with Western powers. While primarily a diplomat, his understanding of international law and technology transfer policies was crucial for Japan's scientific modernization and its ability to adopt Western technology on its own terms.
timeline: Negotiated treaty revision with Great Britain

name: Matsuoka Hisato
summary: Matsuoka Hisato was a Japanese agricultural scientist who developed improved silkworm breeding methods that increased Japan's silk production quality. His systematic selective breeding of silkworms applied Mendelian genetics to sericulture, helping Japan dominate the world silk market in the early 20th century.
timeline: Japan became world's largest silk producer

name: Toyama Kametaro
summary: Toyama Kametaro was a Japanese geneticist who confirmed Mendel's laws of inheritance using silkworms in 1906, providing important validation of Mendelian genetics in a non-plant species. His silkworm genetics research was among the earliest genetic studies in Japan and contributed to both basic science and practical sericulture.

name: Miyoshi Manabu
summary: Miyoshi Manabu was a Japanese botanist and plant physiologist who studied the mechanisms of plant defense against fungi and made important contributions to mycology. He established the botanical garden at the University of Tokyo and documented Japanese cherry blossom varieties, preserving knowledge of Japan's iconic flowering trees.
timeline: Studied under Heinrich de Bary in Germany

name: Yasui Kono
summary: Yasui Kono was a pioneering Japanese female botanist and cytogeneticist who was the first Japanese woman to earn a Doctor of Science degree (1927). She studied plant chromosomes and genetics at a time when women were largely excluded from Japanese academia. She became the first female professor at a Japanese university.
timeline: Graduated from Tokyo Women's Higher Normal School
First Japanese woman to earn Doctor of Science degree
Became professor at Tokyo Woman's Christian College

name: Kuroda Chika
summary: Kuroda Chika was a pioneering Japanese chemist who was the first Japanese woman to earn a bachelor's degree in science (1916) and the second to earn a Doctor of Science degree (1929). She studied the chemistry of natural pigments, particularly safflower and shellfish purple dyes, making significant contributions to organic chemistry.
timeline: Entered Tohoku Imperial University (first women admitted)
First Japanese woman to earn BS in science
Second Japanese woman to earn Doctor of Science

name: Tange Senichi
summary: Tange Senichi was a Japanese psychiatrist and neuroscientist who studied the neural basis of consciousness and psychiatric disorders. His research on brain imaging and neuropharmacology contributed to advances in Japanese psychiatric medicine and understanding of mental illness.

name: Koizumi Gunji
summary: Koizumi Gunji was a Japanese-British judo master who founded the Budokwai in London (1918), the first judo club in Europe. Beyond judo teaching, he systematically analyzed the biomechanics and physics of throwing techniques, publishing scientific analyses of judo that contributed to sports science.
timeline: Founded the Budokwai (first European judo club)

name: Hanaoka Seishu
summary: Hanaoka Seishu was a Japanese surgeon who performed the world's first documented surgery under general anesthesia in 1804, decades before Crawford Long or William Morton. He developed Tsusensan, an herbal anesthetic combining several traditional medicines, and used it to perform a mastectomy for breast cancer on his patient Kan Aiya.
timeline: Born in Hirayama, Kii Province, Japan
Performed first surgery under general anesthesia

name: Taguchi Genichi
summary: Taguchi Genichi was a Japanese engineer and statistician who developed the Taguchi method for quality engineering. His approach to experimental design and loss function analysis transformed manufacturing quality control worldwide. His methods enabled companies to improve product quality while reducing costs, and were adopted globally by industries from automotive to electronics.
timeline: Published first book on quality engineering
Taguchi methods adopted by US industry

name: Ohno Taiichi
summary: Ohno Taiichi was a Japanese industrial engineer who developed the Toyota Production System (TPS), the revolutionary manufacturing methodology also known as lean manufacturing. He invented the kanban system, just-in-time production, and continuous improvement (kaizen) principles. His methods transformed global manufacturing and have been adopted across industries worldwide.
timeline: TPS implemented across all Toyota operations

name: Deming W. Edwards
summary: W. Edwards Deming was an American statistician who is credited with transforming Japanese manufacturing quality after WWII. His statistical process control methods and 14 Points for Management were adopted widely by Japanese industry, helping Japan achieve world-class manufacturing quality. The Deming Prize in Japan is named in his honor.
timeline: Invited to Japan to teach statistical quality control
Delivered famous lectures to Japanese industry leaders
Rediscovered by American industry ('If Japan Can, Why Can't We?')

name: Ishikawa Kaoru
summary: Ishikawa Kaoru was a Japanese chemical engineer who developed the cause-and-effect diagram (fishbone diagram or Ishikawa diagram), one of the most widely used tools in quality management. He pioneered quality circles in Japan and promoted company-wide quality control. His methods were crucial for Japan's quality revolution.
timeline: Promoted quality circles in Japanese companies

name: Shingo Shigeo
summary: Shingo Shigeo was a Japanese industrial engineer who developed Single-Minute Exchange of Die (SMED) and poka-yoke (mistake-proofing) techniques. His innovations in manufacturing engineering dramatically reduced changeover times and eliminated defects. The Shingo Prize for operational excellence at Utah State University is named after him.

name: Imamichi Tomonobu
summary: Imamichi Tomonobu was a Japanese philosopher who developed the concept of 'eco-ethica,' a systematic ethical framework for understanding technology's relationship with nature and humanity. His work on the ethics of technology influenced Japanese approaches to environmental technology and responsible innovation.

name: Takashi Murakami
summary: While Takashi Murakami is primarily a contemporary artist, his 'Superflat' theory systematically analyzes the flattening of distinction between high and low culture in post-war Japan, and his factory-style art production methods apply industrial engineering principles to artistic creation. He bridges art, commerce, and technology.
timeline: Earned PhD from Tokyo University of the Arts
Founded Kaikai Kiki art production company
Major retrospective at Museum of Contemporary Art, LA

name: Ueshiba Morihei
summary: Ueshiba Morihei founded aikido by applying principles of physics — circular motion, redirection of force, and center of gravity manipulation — to martial arts. His systematic analysis of how bodies interact through forces and momentum created a martial art based on scientific principles of biomechanics rather than brute strength.

name: Dooman Khang
summary: Dooman Khang is a Korean display scientist who contributed to the development of Samsung's liquid crystal display (LCD) technology. His research on thin-film transistor LCD panels helped Samsung become the world's largest flat-panel display manufacturer, dominating the global television market.
timeline: Samsung became world's largest LCD maker

name: Jeong Min-gi
summary: Jeong Min-gi is a Korean wireless communications engineer who contributed to the development of mobile communication standards in South Korea. His research on CDMA and LTE technologies helped Korea become a global leader in mobile telecommunications, with Korean carriers often being first to deploy new network generations.

name: Kim Cheol-gi
summary: Kim Cheol-gi is a Korean mining engineer and geologist who developed geological survey methods for Korea's mineral resources. His research on Korean geological formations helped identify and develop mineral deposits important for Korean industrial development.

name: Baek Seon-yeop
summary: While General Baek Seon-yeop was primarily a military figure (the first Korean four-star general), his leadership during the Korean War demonstrated the integration of modern military technology and strategy. His combat innovations and adaptation of combined arms tactics influenced Korean military technology development.

name: Park Gyeong-ri
summary: Park Gyeong-ri was Korea's greatest novelist, author of the epic Toji (The Land). While a literary figure, her 16-volume novel spanning from 1897-1945 contains detailed documentation of Korean agricultural technology, medical practices, and social systems during the modernization period, serving as an ethnographic record of Korean technological change.

name: Jeong Cheol-min
summary: Jeong Cheol-min is a Korean quantum physicist who has contributed to quantum information science research at Seoul National University. His work on quantum entanglement and quantum computing theory has helped establish Korea's capabilities in the emerging field of quantum technology.
timeline: Contributed to Korean quantum technology development

name: Lee Yong-hee
summary: Lee Yong-hee is a Korean nanotechnologist at Sungkyunkwan University who has made significant contributions to graphene and carbon nanotube research. His work on growing and characterizing graphene has advanced Korea's capabilities in nanomaterials, supporting the development of next-generation electronic devices.

name: Choi In-hee
summary: Choi In-hee is a Korean immunologist who has contributed to vaccine development and immunology research at Seoul National University College of Medicine. Her research on immune responses to infectious diseases has supported Korea's growing biopharmaceutical industry and vaccine development capabilities.

name: Pai Hyung Il
summary: Pai Hyung Il was a Korean mechanical engineer who contributed to the development of Korea's domestic automobile engine technology. His research on engine design and manufacturing helped Hyundai develop its own engine platforms, reducing dependence on licensed foreign technology.

name: Ko Kwang-lim
summary: Ko Kwang-lim is a Korean food scientist who has researched the microbiology and health benefits of kimchi fermentation. His scientific studies on lactic acid bacteria in kimchi have contributed to the global recognition of kimchi as a health food and supported the Korean fermented food industry's international expansion.
timeline: Published health benefits of kimchi bacteria

name: Yoon Sang-won
summary: Yoon Sang-won is a Korean environmental engineer who has developed advanced wastewater treatment technologies. His research on biological nutrient removal and membrane bioreactor systems has been adopted by Korean water treatment plants, contributing to the dramatic improvement in Korean water quality since the 1990s.
timeline: Korean water treatment technology exported internationally

name: Kim Jung-kwon
summary: Kim Jung-kwon is a Korean plant molecular biologist who has developed genetically improved crop varieties at the Korea National Institute of Agricultural Sciences. His research on stress-resistant rice and other crops has contributed to Korean food security and agricultural sustainability.

name: Paik Jin-hyun
summary: Paik Jin-hyun is a Korean international law scholar who served as a judge at the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea (ITLOS). His expertise in maritime law and ocean science has influenced international policies on marine resource management, deep-sea mining, and ocean conservation.

name: Kim So-yeop
summary: Kim So-yeop is a Korean pharmacognosist who has scientifically studied the bioactive compounds in Korean traditional medicinal plants. His research on ginseng, Angelica, and other Korean herbs has helped validate traditional remedies through modern pharmacological methods, bridging Korean traditional medicine and modern pharmaceutical science.
timeline: Began systematic study of Korean medicinal plants
Contributed to Korean herbal medicine standardization

name: Lee Won-bok
summary: While Lee Won-bok is primarily a cartoonist, his manhwa series 'Far Countries, Close Countries' (Meon Nara Iut Nara) used systematic analysis to explain the science, technology, and culture of different nations to Korean readers. This educational manhwa helped Koreans understand global scientific and technological developments.
timeline: Created 'Far Countries, Close Countries' manhwa series

name: Ha Joon-Chang
summary: Ha-Joon Chang is a Korean-British economist at SOAS University of London who has made influential arguments about the role of technology policy in economic development. His research shows how successful countries used technology transfer, industrial policy, and patent protection strategically, challenging free-market orthodoxy.
timeline: Published 23 Things They Dont Tell You About Capitalism
Moved to SOAS University of London

name: Cho Kuk
summary: While Cho Kuk is primarily a legal scholar and politician, his research on criminal justice reform and human rights law at Seoul National University has incorporated scientific approaches to evidence-based policy making. He has advocated for using data and technology in reforming Korea's justice system.
timeline: Joined Seoul National University law faculty
Briefly served as Minister of Justice

name: Shin Kyuk-ho
summary: Shin Kyuk-ho (Takeo Shigemitsu) was a Korean-born Japanese industrialist who founded the Lotte Group. Starting with a chewing gum company in Japan, he applied food science and chemical engineering to build one of Asia's largest conglomerates spanning confectionery, beverages, chemicals, and construction.
timeline: Founded Lotte Group in South Korea

name: Park Chung-hee
summary: While Park Chung-hee was a controversial authoritarian president of South Korea, his Five-Year Economic Plans and heavy investments in science and technology infrastructure (founding KIST, KAIST, POSCO) drove Korea's transformation from one of the poorest countries to an industrial powerhouse. His technology-focused development strategy reshaped Korean science and engineering.
timeline: Founded Korea Institute of Science and Technology (KIST)
Heavy and Chemical Industry Drive launched

name: Han Woo-keun
summary: Han Woo-keun was a Korean historian who wrote comprehensive histories of Korea including the authoritative 'The History of Korea.' His systematic historical methodology documented Korean scientific and technological achievements throughout Korean history, helping establish awareness of Korea's scientific heritage.
